text: diving is different nut to crack as far
as pictures there are as many good spots
to shoot from the background is really
important to try and get something where
you have a clean background and not you
know spectators you really have to work
and making a decent diving picture
especially the synchronized diving the
synchronized diving is really difficult
because obviously they're both spinning
at the same time and you both got to
keep them in the frame and it's a tough
sport to shoot it really is probably one
of the toughest I've done the 4 by 100
race was probably the most exciting race
I've ever been associated with comeback
by the Americans was not something I
expected when I looked down in the pool
on the last leg and saw that the
American was probably almost a length
behind the French swimmer and the place
was just so loud you could barely hear
and then the look call Michael Phelps
his face when he realized they had one
and not only one but one the world
record he first reacted toward President
Bush and then turned towards the
American fans on the other side and all
of his teammates and pictures from that
race were phenomenal I mean I was you
know really honored to be there and just
great to be a part of it President Bush
arrived and kind of squinted a little
bit and then waved and so I way back
well I see him quite often at the White
House I cover the White House almost
daily and I'm sure it probably took him
by surprise at first to see me sitting
over there not across from him in the
Oval Office but across from him in the
swimming pool I mean it's just it's it's
it's a great great time I'm amazed at
the world records that are being broken
and I'm sure they'll continue the rest
of the week this is Doug Mills
photographer with the New York Times
